There's a raw, unfiltered emotion that people put into their private lives—intimate moments, vulnerable expressions, personal connections—and to expose that to the public is to strip away the illusion of control they think they have. It's fascinating to watch the unraveling. The shame, the fear, the desperation—it's all so much more vivid than anything you see on a screen or in a movie.

The more they suffer, the more I feel a sense of satisfaction. It's not just the act of exposing them—it's the ripple effect. Their relationships shatter, their careers fall apart, their self-worth is destroyed. I like knowing I played a part in that. It’s a kind of power, and power is addictive.

I don’t see it as cruel. I see it as real. They thought they could hide, but everyone has a weakness. I just find it and show it to the world. And the world watches. That’s the beauty of it.
